title: Web development
summary: Web development is the work involved in developing a website for the Internet ( World Wide Web ) or an intranet (a private network). [ 1 ] Web development can range from developing a simple single static page of plain text to complex web applications , electronic businesses , and social network services . A more comprehensive list of tasks to which Web development commonly refers, may include Web engineering , Web design , Web content development , client liaison, client-side / server-side scripting , Web server and network security configuration, and e-commerce development. Among Web professionals, "Web development" usually refers to the main non-design aspects of building Web sites: writing markup and coding . [ 2 ] Web development may use content management systems (CMS) to make content changes easier and available with basic technical skills.

quiz.question: Among Web professionals, what does "Web development" usually refer to?
options: A) Designing visual layouts and user interfaces.
C) Creating marketing strategies for websites.
D) Managing client liaison and content creation.
quiz.explanation: The article states, "Among Web professionals, 'Web development' usually refers to the main non-design aspects of building Web sites: writing markup and coding."

quiz.question: Who created the World Wide Web in 1989?
quiz.explanation: The article states, "Tim Berners-Lee created the World Wide Web in 1989 at CERN."

quiz.question: Which version of the web is characterized by increased user engagement, communication, and is often referred to as a user-focused, read-write online network?
quiz.explanation: The article describes Web 2.0 as emphasizing interactivity, increased user engagement and communication, and being a user-focused, read-write online network.

quiz.question: According to Debra Howcraft and John Carroll, what is a significant drawback of the Waterfall methodology when applied to website development?
options: A) It requires too many developers.
B) Its rigid structure lacks iteration beyond adjacent stages.
C) It does not cover the entire lifecycle of a development project.
D) It prioritizes speed over quality.
quiz.answer: B) Its rigid structure lacks iteration beyond adjacent stages.
quiz.explanation: The article states, "However, a significant drawback when applying the waterfall methodology to the development of websites (as well as information systems) lies in its rigid structure, lacking iteration beyond adjacent stages."
